item.description:
"The way of even the most justifiable revolutions is prepared by personal impulses disguised into creeds."

Set in the late nineteenth-century London and inspired by an actual attempt to blow up the Greenwich Observatory, The Secret Agent is a complex exploration of motivations.  Dark, and darkly comic, it is the story of a band of spies, anarchists, agents-provocateurs plotting and counter-plotting in the back streets of London. The novel centers on Verloc, a shop-owner, phony-anarchist and double-agent who becomes embroiled in an ambitious terrorist plan. However things go disastrously wrong and what initially appears to be "a simple tale" begins to involve politicians, policemen, foreign diplomats and London's fashionable society in the darkest and most surprising interrelations.

group.name: Classic Books: Book Club for Die-hard Readers

item.name: Conrad: The Secret Agent: A Simple Tale
